newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot natgas still strong with cold weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot natgas still strong with cold weather.

text.p: U.S. spot natgas prices were up only marginally in most markets Monday, despite the significantly below-normal temperatures in the eastern half of the U.S., industry sources said.
Sources attributed the lack of rally to forecasts for warmer air seen returning next week.
Gulf Coast gas traded in the high-$2.60s to mid-$2.70s, unchanged to about two cents higher from Friday's levels.
At the New York city-gate, however, prices soared into the high-$3.20s to low-$3.40s as temperatures are expected to be at least 10 degrees below-normal in the Northeast this week.
In the Midcontinent, where temperatures are expected to be about 10 to 20 degrees below-normal this week, prices gained two to four cents to the low-$2.60s.
The Chicago city-gate market was steady to slightly stronger in the high-$2.80s to mid-$2.90s.
In west Texas, Permian prices climbed about three cents to the low-to-mid $2.50s, while at Waha gas traded in the mid-$2.50s to low-$2.60s.
At the southern California border, traders reported closing deals in the mid-$2.60s as temperatures hovered just above-normal.
To avoid moving the spot market much higher, buyers may be turning to storage supplies to meet the strong heating demand in the Northeast and Midwest, traders said.
